awd_titl_txt: NeTS:  Small:   Collaborative Research:  Cooperative Interference-Embracing Communication in Multi-Hop Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
While the proliferation of wireless devices and their Internet-centered applications has brought forth numerous wireless services, current wireless technologies are unable to meet the increasing communication demand caused by the huge number of wireless devices and the scarcity of available radio spectrum. The proposed research will make a concrete step toward bridging this gap by developing new communication algorithms and protocols for wireless networks, specifically multi-hop wireless networks. Multi-hop communication brings many benefits such as enlarged network coverage, reduced radio transmit power, and relaxed requirements for network infrastructure, yet interference severely degrades network performance. This project investigates this fundamental issue by developing practical approaches to managing interference in multi-hop wireless networks, with the objective of maximizing their throughput performance. The success of this project will advance the field's knowledge of wireless system design and implementation, significantly improve network throughput performance, and enlarge the network communication coverage, yielding ubiquitous high data rate wireless services. The project will also provide opportunities for research training for underrepresented students at undergraduate and graduate levels, and project results will be widely disseminated through high-profile tutorials, talks, publications, software toolkits, and open-source sites. 

The goal of this project is to develop novel, practical, and foundational interference-embracing solutions to improve the throughput of multi-hop wireless networks by leveraging recent advances in physical layer techniques, and to evaluate such solutions using real-world implementations. Focusing on theory, protocol design, and system prototyping for interference management technologies, this project presents a comprehensive solution for advanced interference management in multi-hop wireless networks, including interference cancellation, interference alignment, and interference neutralization. In addition to significantly advancing interference management techniques for multi-hop wireless communications, this project will provide training opportunities for students spanning signal processing, optimization, algorithmic development, and networking infrastructure research; support talented female and underrepresented Ph.D. students in the completion of their doctoral studies; result in the dissemination of research results through high-profile tutorials, talks, publications, software toolkits, and open-source sites; and integrate research results into the development of new courses at both the University of Louisville and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

por.por_cntn:
While the proliferation of wireless devices and their Internet-centered data-intensive applications have brought forth numerous wireless services, current wireless technologies are often unable to meet the rapidly increasing communication demand. This gap between the demand and capacity is mainly caused by the huge number of wireless devices and the scarcity of available wireless spectrum. The proposed research makes a concrete step towards bridging this gap by developing new communication algorithms and protocols for the emerging wireless networks and systems. Complementary to the centralized communication systems, the distributed communication systems bring many benefits such as enlarged network coverage, reduced radio transmit power, and relaxed requirements for network infrastructure, yet interference severely degrades the network performance. This research investigates this fundamental issue by developing practical approaches and systems to manage interference in different types of wireless networks, with the objective of maximizing their throughput performance. Specifically, this research exploits the recent advances in Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO), machine learning, signal processing, cross-technology communication, and software-defined radio technologies to improve the communication efficiency and security in a large-scale distributed network with massive IoT devices. The outcomes of this research have advanced the state-of-the-art of interference management in the following aspects.

First, this research develops novel, practical, and foundational interference-embracing solutions for uplink MU-MIMO (multi-user MIMO) and NOMA (non-orthogonal multiple access) in the wireless networks to improve the throughput by leveraging recent advances in physical-layer techniques, and evaluates such solutions using real-world implementations. These new communication schemes could greatly benefit the wireless research community. Second, this research investigates the interference management in emerging wireless networks, such as distributed MIMO, vehicular, and IoT LoRa networks, and proposes communication schemes to improve the decoding performance using a blend of signal processing and deep neural network (DNN) based machine learning techniques. Third, the research systematically studies the coexistence of multiple wireless technologies and discovers new applications such as jamming resilient communication. Specifically, this research proposes a transparent coexistence system for WiFi and LTE-U (LTE on Unlicensed spectrum bands) on the same spectrum band, and presents another coexistence system for MU-MIMO and D2D (device-to-device) communication in a cellular network. Multiple systems are developed to addresses the challenges of communication under severe intentional or inadvertent interference. 

Focusing on theory, protocol design, and system prototyping for interference management technologies, this project advances interference management in wireless systems, in the directions of interference cancellation, interference alignment, and interference neutralization. The project also makes an important educational impact via the creation of new wireless communication course projects and modules, widening students' views of spanning signal processing, optimization, algorithmic development, and networking infrastructure research. This project has contributed to the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, resulting in the dissemination of research results through high-profile tutorials, talks, and publications, including two best paper awards from prestigious networking conferences. The research results have been integrated into the development of new courses and K-12 training materials at the Michigan State University.
